Controversy Explanation: Law school students protested a Federalist Society-organized panel discussion on civil liberties featuring Monica Miller and Kristen Waggoner, moderated by Stith, because of Waggoner's stance on LGBTQ issues. Students also claimed that the university was putting the free speech concerns of the panel ahead of the free speech concerns of students by having police present who supposedly intimidated protesters. The protesters began interrupting the event when the moderator tried to introduce the panel. The interruptions continued throughout the event in the form of heckling inside the hall and stomping, shouting, clapping, singing, and pounding the walls outside the room, loudly enough that it was difficult to hear the speakers. The associate dean of the law school was present the entire time and never confronted any of the protesters. Nearly three weeks later, the law school dean issued a statement saying the protesters' behavior was “unacceptable" but that it did not violate the school's free expression policy.
Public Response: Neutral (Disingenuous), Appeased Protesters. Several weeks after the event, the law school dean issued a statement that included: "In accordance with the University’s free expression policy, which includes a three-warning protocol, those protesting exited the room after the first warning, and the event went forward. . . .Together, we will figure out how to nurture a thriving intellectual environment while maintaining a community of equality and mutual respect. It is harder than ever to find common ground; the stakes are high, and the rights of cherished members of our own community are under attack. But it is essential that we keep this community together despite the many forces seeking to divide us."

Controversy Explanation: Law school students protested a Federalist Society-organized panel discussion on civil liberties featuring Waggoner and Monica Miller moderated by Kate Stith, because of Waggoner's stance on LGBTQ issues. Students also claimed that the university was putting the free speech concerns of the panel ahead of the free speech concerns of students by having police present who supposedly intimidated protesters. The protesters began interrupting the event when the moderator tried to introduce the panel. The interruptions continued throughout the event in the form of heckling inside the hall and stomping, shouting, clapping, singing, and pounding the walls outside the room, loudly enough that it was difficult to hear the speakers. The associate dean of the law school was present the entire time and never confronted any of the protesters. Nearly three weeks later, the law school dean issued a statement saying the protesters' behavior was “unacceptable" but that it did not violate the school's free expression policy.
Public Response: Neutral (Disingenuous). The law school released a statement claiming that Yale police officers "were already on hand [when the panel started and] . . . that assistance was not needed and the event went forward until its conclusion."

Controversy Explanation: Law school students protested a Federalist Society-organized panel discussion on civil liberties featuring Miller and Kristen Waggoner, moderated by Kate Stith, because of Waggoner's stance on LGBTQ issues. Students also claimed that the university was putting the free speech concerns of the panel ahead of the free speech concerns of students by having police present who supposedly intimidated protesters. The protesters began interrupting the event when the moderator tried to introduce the panel. The interruptions continued throughout the event in the form of heckling inside the hall and stomping, shouting, clapping, singing, and pounding the walls outside the room, loudly enough that it was difficult to hear the speakers. The associate dean of the law school was present the entire time and never confronted any of the protesters. Nearly three weeks later, the law school dean issued a statement saying the protesters' behavior was “unacceptable" but that it did not violate the school's free expression policy.
Public Response: Neutral (Disingenuous). The law school released a statement claiming that Yale police officers "were already on hand [when the panel started and] . . . that assistance was not needed and the event went forward until its conclusion."

School: Yeshiva University, Benjamin Cardozo Law School
Controversy Explanation: The university president canceled an event featuring Abdulhadi, citing Abdulhadi's past support of a U.S.-designated terrorist organization. Students petitioned the administration to reverse its decision.
Public Response: Condemned Content of Expression. The university president wrote: “As the flagship Jewish university, Yeshiva University proudly supports Israel and its right to exist as central to our core values. In that spirit, we made a recent decision to cancel a student-scheduled guest speaker at Cardozo Law School. . . .While I know that our students were well-intentioned, all people of good conscience must stand against hate. Spirited debate about government policy and sanctions cannot descend into advocacy of violence. . . .The current anti-Semitic vitriol on college campuses today that so often uses anti-Israel rhetoric will find no home or harbor at this university.”

Controversy Explanation: A student fellow affiliated with the Ayaan Hirsi Ali Foundation worked with the Brown RISD Hillel to invite Boghossian to speak on campus. After the student began to advertise the event they were contacted by an administrator to answer questions about the event. The next day the Brown HISD Hillel informed the student that the event featuring Boghossian could no longer be held and the event was canceled, presumably because of his role in The Grievance Studies controversy.

After a post-performancce discussion among students and faculty about the play's message and whether it promoted racism and homophobia instead of trying to correct them, the remaining performances of the play were canceled because of the play's "excessive racism and homophobia."
Public Response: Neutral, Appeased Protesters: In a statement the college said: "Despite efforts to have a post-performance discussion, issues related to the script's dialogue and the production's themes understandably raised a number of concerns within the campus community. Plans are being developed for a wider campus discussion to address those concerns which remain as well as the broader issues which underlie them."

Controversy Explanation: The campus chapter of Turning Point USA worked with an off-campus activist group, the Leadership Insitute, to host a Youth Leadership Workshop with Tomaine as an invited speaker. An Antifa Twitter account, Antifascist Runor Mill, encuraged students opposed to Tomaine's appearance to fill seats and disrupt the event and tweeted a picture of Tomain's headshot with a red line through it. The college provided extra security for the event, which occurred without disruption.

School: State University of New York at Buffalo
Controversy Explanation: Young Americans for Freedom invited West to speak on campus. West's appearance was protested by students, who organized a walkout of classes on the day of West's speaking event. West completed his speech but the Q&A session was disrupted by student protesters and ended abruptly. West was then escorted out of the event by campus police officers.
Public Response: Honor Roll, Neutral.  In a statement the university said: "As a public university, all members of the UB community and invited guests have a right to peacefully express their views and opinions, regardless of whether others may disagree. This includes the right of individuals to oppose the views or opinions of others – including peaceful protests – but not in such a way as to limit or prevent the speaker’s freedom of expression or interfere with university operations. West was invited to campus by the UB student chapter of the Young Americans for Freedom. Student government-sponsored clubs are permitted to invite speakers to campus, provided they abide by university guidelines and state laws concerning public events on campus."

Controversy Explanation: The Purdue Student Union Board planned to host an event called "Sex in the Dark", a sex education presentation that would allow students to ask anonymous questions to two "sex experts". However, administrators postponed the event after receiving complaints from another student group called Boiler Catholics that the event was "promoting premarital sex and hookup culture." The event does not appear to have been rescheduled.
Public Response: Neutral (Disingenuous).  In a statement the director of student activities and organizations said: "The postponement, like for many events, was to better the event, and in this case we want to make a greater impact on the student body. This event will happen in the spring and our goal is to increase the number of people as well as the scale of the event."

Controversy Explanation: The Jewish non-profit organization Stop Antisemitism called on Northeastern (and the University of California, San Diego) to cancel Herzallah's talk on campus because of he is a "dangerous antisemite." Herzallah's talk at Northeastern was either canceled or moved off-campus, and Stop Antisemitism thanked Norteastern's administration and its president.

After controversies over the annual performance of Draggieland at, a three-day summer event for incoming freshmen, in 2020 and 2021, university administrators pulled all sponsorhip and funding for the performance. LGBT student groups successfully raised enough money to put the performance on without university funding.

The Young Conservatives of Texas invited Coulter to speak on campus and were initially informed they would be charged more than $2,624 in safety fees for the event. However, due to controversy over Coulter on a different campus, the safety fees were increased to $3,410.38 shortly before the event. State Representative Briscoe Cain spoke with the university's Vice President for Governmental Relations on behalf of the Young Conservatives of Texas, and explained that the consideration of "any anticipated controversy" violates the Texas Education Code. The safety costs were reduced and Coulter spoke successfully.
Public Response: Neutral (Disingenuous). In a statement the university vice president of media relations said: "The University of Houston is committed to fostering a learning environment where free inquiry and expression are encouraged. Decisions about the use of campus facilities and related fees for expressive activity by students, faculty, and staff are not based on the content or viewpoint of a proposed expressive activity ... It is correct to say that state law provides that a university may not consider any anticipated controversy related to the event in determining the amount of a fee to be charged for use of the institution’s facilities. The interactive process within the university did result in a change in the proposed fees."

Controversy Explanation: After the College Republicans invited Sessions to speak on campus, the student government passed a resolution demanding a postponement of the time so that it did not occur during Black History Month because Sessions had previously made "racist" comments. The College Republicans condemned the resolution and Sessions spoke on campus successfully.

The campus chapter of Students for Life invited Fevig to speak on campus. About a week prior to the event, Students for Life were informed by university administrators that they would have to pay the full price for hosting the event on campus, after previously being told that they would pay a discounted fee. The administration also informed Students for Life that they had not yet filed a form and even if they did now the university "didn’t want to risk the integrity of Election Day should there be a negative response" because the event space is also a polling place. Students for Life parterned with a local chapter of Americans for Prosperity and held the event off-campus instead.

School: State University of New York, Platsburgh
Controversy Explanation: Moezzi was invited to perform his comedic act on campus by the university's Student Association. After student complaints that Moezzi was "transphobic" and "obviously racist," the Student Association canceled his performance.

The Fourth Wall Theater, a student-run theater organization at the university, decided to not perform Perfect Arrangement after some of the student actors in the performance raised concerns about the play's derogatory language that demeans LGBTQ people . Alice in Wonderland was performed instead.

A student group called for the college to cancel Stern’s presentations to the college's diversity, equity, and inclusion board over Stern's views on anti-Semitism, claiming Stern has been “instrumental in cementing the erroneous conflation of Judaism and Zionism.” Stern spoke successfully.

The university allegedly canceled Davis' talk because of her support for the Boycott, Divestment, and Sanctions movement. The university claimed that the sponsoring organization didn't follow the proper procedures for scheduling the event.
Public Response: Neutral (Disingenuous). A university spokesperson stated: "Allegations that the event was canceled due to pressure from students who had concerns about the speaker and the content of the program are completely false. . . .The university’s policy for securing outside speakers was not followed."

Controversy Topic(s): Abortion, Gender, Political Views, Race, Sexuality
Controversy Explanation: Students and alumni petitioned administrators to cancel a Cardinals for Life event featuring Johnson, describing Johnson's past statements as racist, homophobic, and anti-LGBTQ and objecting to her support of Donald Trump. After being "pressured" by the university chaplain, the group who invited Johnson canceled the event and its leader resigned. Sponsorship of Johnson's speech was taken over by the College Republicans and she spoke as originally planned.
Public Response:
Honor Roll
Neutral. The university president told reporters: “The event will take place as planned. . . . An event for students who oppose Ms. Johnson’s presentation will be held at the same time.”

Controversy Explanation: Students petitioned the unversity to disinvite Lahren from campus because of Lahren's views on immigration, Black Lives Matter, and other social and political issues. Lahren spoke successfully.
Public Response: Neutral. The Campus Police Chief said: "Our goal here is to maintain the safety and the security of the campus as well as everyone that’s coming to this event. . . .That's our goal for every activity that we have on campus, so it's really not going to look any different from what people will see at any normal event; a football game, where we are expecting significant numbers of people."

Controversy Explanation: Students called on the university and the journalism department to disinvite Zorn because of his opinions and writing on race, policing, and crime. The university chapter of the Society of Professional Journalists pulled its support for the event because Zorn was invited. Zorn withdrew from the panel, stating, "My presence here would distract from the agenda and be unfair to my friends on the panel."

TFP Student Action, an off-campus organization, petitioned the university president to disinvite Martin from delivering a campus speech because of Martin's views on contraception and homosexuality and his other religious positions. Martin spoke successfully.

Two faculty members and an off-campus environmental protection group called for the university to disinvite Lomborg from lecturing, objecting to Lomborg's views on climate change. Lomborg spoke successfully.
Students interrupted a speaking event by Stras by reading prepared remarks critical of Stras' decisions and statements related to LGBTQ+ anti-discrimination issues.

Administrators claimed that the campus chapter of Turning Point USA did not follow proper procedures for receiving approval to have Basrawi speak. The student group claimed the administration was putting up bureaucratic roadblocks because it disagreed with the speaker's views on critical race theory. The event was held successfully off campus.

Controversy Topic(s): Gender, Israeli-Palestinian Conflict, Political Views, Race, Sexuality
Controversy Explanation: Students and the campus chapter of Students for a Democratic Soceity petitioned the university to disinvite Shapiro due to Shapiro's views on race, immigration, sexual orientation, and other topics. Shapiro spoke successfully.
Public Response:
Honor Roll, High Honors
Neutral. A university spokesperson told reporters that FSU “is committed to promoting an environment where the entire community can freely discuss and exchange different beliefs and opinions. . . . FSU encourages recognized student organizations to invite different individuals and groups to speak on campus, and they have the right to do so, even if other students disagree with the ideas that may be presented."

School: Harvard University, T.H. Chan School of Public Health
Controversy Explanation: Students petitioned the Chan School of Public Health to disinvite Ghebreyesus from delivering a commencement speech and to rescind the award it planned to give Ghebreyesus because of the policies Ghebreyesus implemented while serving as Ethiopia's minister of health and the effect of those policies on marginalized communities. Ghebreyesus spoke successfully.

Speaker/Performer/Title: Donna Harrison, & representatives from O’Connor House and the Hope Center
Controversy Explanation: Harrison (and Julia DeLuce) and other representatives from a pro-life group were ridiculed by a faculty member, who sent an email to faculty chairs demanding the group's event regarding sexual assault victims with unplanned pregnancies be canceled or drastically modified. Harrison spoke successfully.

Speaker/Performer/Title: Julia DeLuce & representatives from O’Connor House and the Hope Center
Controversy Explanation: DeLuce (and Donna Harrison) and other representatives from a pro-life group were ridiculed by a faculty member, who sent an email to faculty chairs, demanding the group's event regarding unplanned pregnancy among sexual assault victims be canceled or drastically modified. DeLuce spoke successfully.

TFP Student Action, an off-campus organization, called on Catholics to join in a prayerful petition to cancel Martin's talk at the university, objecting to Martin's acceptance of homosexuality — including gay marriage, gay kissing during mass, and the invitation of gay people to be Eucharistic ministers — and "his support" for transgenderism for children. The petition garnered more than 20,000 signatures but Martin spoke successfully.

The science department that invited Abbot to deliver a campus lecture disinvited him to avoid controversy in the wake of online criticism of Abbot’s views on diversity, equity, and inclusion initiatives.
Public Response: Condemned Content of Expression, Appeased Protesters. The president of the university's email to the university community included:  “[The] controversy around this situation has caused great distress for many members of our community, in many quarters. It has also uncovered significant differences within the institute on several issues. . . . [Our community has] suffered a tide of online targeting and hate mail from outside MIT . . . [and the head of the event organizing department] could not host an effective public outreach event centered around Professor Abbot. . . .[and instead disinvited Abbot] deliberately to preserve the opportunity for free dialogue and open scientific exchange.”

School: Massachusetts Institute of Technology, Sloan School of Management
Controversy Explanation: A student group petitioned the university to stop Eisin from speaking because Eisen is a retired colonel of the Israel Defense Forces. Eisin spoke successfully.

An off-campus organization emailed people, asking them to contact the university to ask it not to host a town hall event featuring Biden because of Biden's views on abortion. Biden spoke successfully.
Public Response: Neutral. The university put out a statement that said: "The decision to permit the CNN Town Hall to take place at Mount St. Joseph is consistent with the University’s policies and mission to embrace a diverse and inclusive place where people from different races, ethnicities, social backgrounds, beliefs, and religions can come together to discuss and share their unique perspectives."

Source(s): Faculty, General Public, Politician(s), Student Group(s), Student(s)
Controversy Explanation: Students created a petition asking the university to prevent Yiannopoulos from coming to campus. Some faculty members filed bias complaints with the university administration, and a student group called for Uncensored America, the host of the event, to be stripped of its registered status. Some faculty condemned Yiannopoulos in a public statement reading, “As faculty members, we are concerned that this event will create a hostile work environment for many faculty, staff and other employees, in particular for our LGBTQ+ colleagues." Yiannopoulos spoke successfully.
Public Response:
Honor Roll
Neutral. In a statement signed by several university administrators, the university took the position: “As a public university, we are fundamentally and unalterably obligated under the U.S. Constitution’s First Amendment to protect various expressive rights, even for those whose viewpoints offend our basic institutional values. . . .To do so otherwise not only violates the Constitution but would undermine the basic freedom each of us shares to generally think and express ourselves as we wish.”

School: Pepperdine University, Caruso School of Law
Controversy Explanation: A coalition of 11 student organizations and a number of protesters petitioned the school to withdraw Volokh's speaking invitation because of Volokh's use of racial slurs. Volokh spoke successfully.
Public Response: Supported Speaker (or Artist) as Person (Not Views). The university issued a statement that included: "Professor Volokh is one of the nation’s leading First Amendment experts. Indeed, just last month he launched a new faculty-edited Journal of Free Speech Law with a board of editors of leading academics with diverse perspectives. We believe having him share his views on the free speech issues facing our country is consistent with the purpose of the Dean’s Speaker Series."

Controversy Explanation: The university encouraged the library to cancel an art exhibit because the centerpiece of the exhibit, a sculpture titled, Faith, was created by a soldier who served in the Confederate army. The library canceled the exhibit.
Public Response: Condemned Speaker (or Artist) as a Person, Encouraged (or Approved of) Self-Censorship. A university spokesperson said: "The ultimate editorial authority over scholarly exhibitions resides with the Library. It is the Library that speaks through its galleries, and the Library is responsible for the messages conveyed there."

Controversy Explanation: Faculty and students called on the college to disinvite Singer from giving a lecture because of Singer's philosophical opinions on the value of human life and, in particular, the disabled. The event proceeded as planned and Singer spoke successfully.
Public Response: Condemned Content of Expression, Appeased Protesters.  The university released a public statement that included: "We are writing to acknowledge that our institution’s spirit of supporting expressive speech does not prohibit Professor Singer’s participation in this virtual panel. At the same time, our community’s values compel us to denounce some of the views he has expressed repeatedly over years through various addresses, writings, and media interviews. Fundamentally, Rhodes College is deeply committed to diversity, equity, and inclusion. These values extend to every member of our community, including individuals with disabilities. While we view the invitation to Peter Singer in light of our commitment to free and open dialogue at a liberal arts college, his views on disability are unequivocally antithetical to our institutional values of diversity, equity and inclusion. We reject and condemn in the most forceful manner possible any views that call into question the value and worth of all human life."

School: Rutgers University, Newark & San Francisco State University
Controversy Topic(s): Israeli-Palestinian Conflict, Terrorism, Criminal or Other Misconduct,
Controversy Explanation: The International Legal Forum organized a petition calling for the cancellation of an event featuring Kumar, among others, because of Sami Al-Arian's and Hatem Bazian's alleged terrorist ties and support. The event was co-sponsored by Rutgers University and San Francisco State University academic departments, among other organizations. Kumar spoke successfully.

The event was co-sponsored by Rutgers University and San Francisco State University academic departments, among other organizations. Ahmed spoke successfully.

The event was co-sponsored by Rutgers University and San Francisco State University academic departments, among other organizations. Masri spoke successfully.

School: Rutgers University, Newark & San Francisco State University
Controversy Topic(s): Israeli-Palestinian Conflict, Terrorism, Criminal or Other Misconduct,
Controversy Explanation: The International Legal Forum organized a petition calling for the cancellation of an event moderated by Kelley, among others, because of Sami Al-Arian's and Hatem Bazian's alleged terrorist ties and support. The event was co-sponsored by Rutgers University and San Francisco State University academic departments, among other organizations. The event occurred successfully.

Controversy Topic(s): Israeli-Palestinian Conflict, Terrorism, Criminal or Other Misconduct,
Controversy Explanation: The International Legal Forum organized a petition calling for the cancellation of an event featuring Al-Arian, among others, because of Al-Arian's (and Hatem Bazian's) alleged terrorist ties and support. The event was co-sponsored by Rutgers University and San Francisco State University academic departments, among other organizations. Al-Arian spoke successfully.

School: Rutgers University, Newark & San Francisco State University
Controversy Topic(s): Israeli-Palestinian Conflict, Terrorism, Criminal or Other Misconduct,
Controversy Explanation: The International Legal Forum organized a petition calling for the cancellation of an event featuring Za3za3, among others, because of Sami Al-Arian's and Hatem Bazian's alleged terrorist ties and support. The event was co-sponsored by Rutgers University and San Francisco State University academic departments, among other organizations. Za3za3 spoke successfully.

Controversy Topic(s): Abortion, Gender, Race, Sexuality, civil liberties
Controversy Explanation: Students and alumni petitioned the university president to disinvite Walsh from lecturing because of his views on feminism and race and his other political opinions. The college church withdrew the church as the venue for the lecture, claiming Walsh “holds positions contrary to the values of our Catholic faith." The event was held off campus instead.
Public Response: Condemned Content of Expression, Appeased Protesters. The campus church released a statement which read: "Following more scrutiny of his statements, we cannot in good conscience give him a platform to speak. . . . [because Walsh] holds positions contrary to the values of our Catholic faith. . . . His provocative positions on immigration, on communities of color, on Muslims, and on members of the LGBTQ community seemed designed to stir anger and resentment, rather than encourage thoughtful dialogue. His statements are in contradiction to Jesus' great commandment to love God and love our neighbor."
